topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade (Beta): Viewing System Alarms

body.p: HP Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade can generate system alarms when operational conditions change on any of the hosts in the cluster.
Note: This feature applies only to servers in the VNF Region.

The supported interfaces to the alarms subsystem are the command line interface (see System Alarms CLI Commands on page 145), the web interface (click the Fault Management menu on the Admin tab), SNMP, and the system REST API.

section.title: About SNMP Support
section.p: Support for SNMP is implemented as follows: * access is disabled by default, must be enabled manually from the command line interface * available using the controller's node floating OAM IP address, over the standard UDP port 161 * supported version is SNMPv2c * access is read-only for all SNMP communities * all SNMP communities have access to the entire OID tree, there is not support for VIEWS * supported SNMP operations are GET, GETNEXT, GETBULK, and SNMPv2C-TRAP2 * the SNMP SET operation is not supported

section.p: The following SNMP attributes are used as follows:

li.p: sysUpTime - Set to the up time of the active controller.
sysServices - Set to the nominal value of 72 to indicate that the host provides services at layers 1 to 7.

section.title: Enterprise MIBs
section.p: The HP Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade supports the Enterprise Registration and Alarm MIBs.

li.p: Enterprise Registration MIB, wrsEnterpriseReg.mib - Defines the hierarchy underneath the iso(1).org(3).dod(6).internet(1).private(4).enterprise(1). This hierarchy is administered as follows:

codeblock.codeph: * .wrs(731), the IANA-registered enterprise code * .wrs(731).wrsCommon(1).wrs<Module>(1-...), defined in wrsCommon<Module>.mib. * .wrs(731).wrsProduct(2-...), defined in wrs<Product>.mib.

li.p: Alarm MIB, wrsAlarmMib.mib - Defines the common TRAP and ALARM MIBs. The definition includes textual conventions, an active alarm table, a historical alarm table, and traps.
Textual Conventions - Semantic statements used to simplify definitions in the active alarm table and traps components of the MIB.

Active Alarm Table - A list of all active or set alarms in the system. Each entry in the table includes the following variables: * UUID * AlarmID * EntityInstanceID * DateAndTime * AlarmSeverity * ReasonText * EventType * ProbableCause * ProposedRepairAction * ServiceAffecting * SuppressionAllowed

section.title: Viewing alarms
section.p: On the web interface, click the Fault Management menu on the Admin tab, and then select the Active Alarms tab.
For more information on accessing the Fault Managemen tab, see Host Status and Alarms During System Configuration Changes.
The Fault Management tab contains two tabs:

ul.li: Historical Alarm Table - A history of set and clear alarm operations in the system. The table includes the same variables as the active alarm table, plus the variable AlarmState used to indicate whether the table entry is a SET or a CLEAR operation.

section.p: Traps Defines the following generic traps:

For all alarms, the Notification Type is based on the severity of the trap or alarm. This is done to facilitate the interaction with most SNMP trap viewers which typically use the Notification Type to drive the coloring of traps, that is, red for critical, yellow for minor, and so on.
For Critical, Major, Minor, Warning, and Message traps, all variables in the active alarm table are included as varbinds.
For the Clear trap, varbinds include only the AlarmID, EntityInstanceID, DateAndTime, and ReasonText variables.
For the HierarchicalClear trap, varbinds include only the EntityInstanceID, DateAndTime, and ReasonText variables.

section.title: Enabling SNMP Support
section.p: In order to have a workable SNMP configuration you must use the command line interface on the active controller to:

ol.li: Define at least one SNMP community string. See Adding an SNMP Community String.
Configure at least one SNMP trap destination so that alarms can be reported as they happen. See Configuring SNMP Trap Destinations.
